title: Is it time for an eye test?
text: Learn more about UV protection “Generally speaking adults should have their eyes tested every two years,” says Andy Hepworth, dispensing optician and professional relations manager for Essilor. “Even if you don’t wear glasses, the test checks for more than just eye health and vision but various health conditions, too, so it’s really important. "What’s more, some people think their vision is fine when actually they just haven’t noticed it slowly deteriorating.” If your optician advises you should go for check-ups more frequently, always follow their recommendation. Here are a few of the more common telltale signs of potential eye problems: You’re afraid of the dark Well, not literally – but if your night vision is poor and you struggle when driving after dark, for example, then it’s time to get booked in. “When there’s less light your eyes will be fighting to see and it can often highlight if you have an issue with your eyesight,” says Hepworth. And no, it’s not a problem that can be solved with carrots alone. You flunk the app test Think your eyesight has worsened? Download the Vision Test app from Essilor (free, iPhone/iPad/Android), which allows you to perform a basic version of an sight test on yourself. You’ll be challenged on how clearly you can see letters of certain sizes, for example, just like you’re in the optician’s chair. Hepworth stresses this should not be a replacement for a check-up with a registered optometrist, but instead is a smart way of flagging up when you need to get one scheduled. “Vision loss could be linked to other health conditions, so you should never delay booking in with your optician if you’ve noticed a significant change in your sight,” he notes. You’re on the blink If you – or someone else – notices that you’ve recently started to blink more or rub your eyes a lot, arrange an eye test,” advises Hepworth. “It could be a sign that your vision has deteriorated, as that can cause a natural impulse to blink to try to clear your vision." You have a family history “If any members of your family have had the eye conditions glaucoma or macular degeneration, or you have diabetes yourself, you will certainly need to see your optician more frequently," says Hepworth. "Once in the eye test they will certainly ask for information around these areas so they can take a special look at any relevant areas.” Watch the video to discover the benefits of Crizal UV Protective Lenses >>
